text: A client (US company with 200 employees) told me they need my credit card details to pay me for the blog post I (a non-US citizen living outside the US) wrote. This is the first time someone asks my CC info for this purpose. Is this normal? Sounds a bit shady as I already sent them all the details for bank wire transfer, provided my PayPal email, and filled W-8BEN form. Also, the same person with whom I exchange emails wanted me to accept being paid based on the word count of the published blog post and not on the word count I deliver based on our agreement. Obviously, I refused. Any suggestion on how to approach the credit card issue? Is it a legit request or? Just want to get my money and never work with them again:)

elements.text: A client (US company with 200 employees) told me they need my credit card details to pay me for the blog post I (a non-US citizen living outside the US) wrote. This is the first time someone asks my CC info for this purpose. Is this normal? Sounds a bit shady as I already sent them all the details for bank wire transfer, provided my PayPal email, and filled W-8BEN form. Also, the same person with whom I exchange emails wanted me to accept being paid based on the word count of the published blog post and not on the word count I deliver based on our agreement. Obviously, I refused. Any suggestion on how to approach the credit card issue? Is it a legit request or? Just want to get my money and never work with them again:)

text:
This doesn't look straight. To my knowledge you don't need the CC detail to send funds to any credit card. Assuming they'd want to send your pay to your credit account.

Still, you should ask more questions and be clear which payment gateway or method or partner they use to do any transaction like this. And do your basic search about the service they use to be sure if this is the case.

text:
Hi everyone!

I'm wondering if anyone has any tips or suggestions on effectively organizing/creating password-protected content on a website? I'm currently working on a project related to this, and want to make sure the experience with the protected content is as smooth as possible for the site visitor. Would greatly appreciate any suggestions!

elements.text:
Hi everyone!

I'm wondering if anyone has any tips or suggestions on effectively organizing/creating password-protected content on a website? I'm currently working on a project related to this, and want to make sure the experience with the protected content is as smooth as possible for the site visitor. Would greatly appreciate any suggestions!

text: oh this is interesting. will readers need to pay first?

elements.text: oh this is interesting. will readers need to pay first?

text: one way you could do this is to create a subdomain for this content and use ghost to publish. they have a built in feature to password protect.

elements.text: one way you could do this is to create a subdomain for this content and use ghost to publish. they have a built in feature to password protect.

text: it applies to any content on that site, which is why you’d need to do it with a subdomain

elements.text: it applies to any content on that site, which is why you’d need to do it with a subdomain

text:
They won't need to pay first. I'm currently working in Squarespace, which has the ability to password-protect specific pages and/or the entire site, but I was just curious if anyone had done something similar before.

It's already an extra step for visitors to have to enter a password (or request one if they don't already have it), so I just want to make the interaction with the actual content as effective and simple as possible :slightly_smiling_face:

text:
Hey everyone,
I am a product marketer. When it comes to branding and coming up with website and collaterals, what nuances should I keep in mind when I need to target two different set of audiences? I need to target small businesses and also enterprises for the same product. Would like to get a piece of your mind on this.

elements.text:
Hey everyone,
I am a product marketer. When it comes to branding and coming up with website and collaterals, what nuances should I keep in mind when I need to target two different set of audiences? I need to target small businesses and also enterprises for the same product. Would like to get a piece of your mind on this.

text:
I don’t have the answer, but Freshbooks targets two big separate audiences (small businesses and freelancers) so I would definitely look at how they do things!

<https://www.freshbooks.com/>

attachments.title: Invoice and Accounting Software for Small Businesses | FreshBooks
attachments.text: The best cloud based small business accounting software. Send invoices, track time, manage receipts, expenses, and accept credit cards. Free 30-day trial.
attachments.fallback: FreshBooks: Invoice and Accounting Software for Small Businesses | FreshBooks

elements.text: I don’t have the answer, but Freshbooks targets two big separate audiences (small businesses and freelancers) so I would definitely look at how they do things!

text: Coincidentally, I had a job interview yesterday and was asked a question very similar to this discussion. How to make Sales as aware as possible of the marketing assets that have been created to support their efforts. And how to get them to make use of the collateral, videos, etc. It turned into a short discussion, during which I referred to this thread, and in the end we agreed that the stand up meetings are the way to go. Gives you a chance to talk up the resources and to solicit ideas from Sales for what they might be looking for in the future.

elements.text: Coincidentally, I had a job interview yesterday and was asked a question very similar to this discussion. How to make Sales as aware as possible of the marketing assets that have been created to support their efforts. And how to get them to make use of the collateral, videos, etc. It turned into a short discussion, during which I referred to this thread, and in the end we agreed that the stand up meetings are the way to go. Gives you a chance to talk up the resources and to solicit ideas from Sales for what they might be looking for in the future.

text:
Let's talk email marketing...When it comes to promotional email blasts for a product, what kinds of things do you like to a/b test in the subject line? For example, here are some things I'm thinking:
Ends soon vs. ends tonight vs. ending soon
Get 30% off vs. take 30% off vs. claim 30% off vs. enjoy 30 % off
Percent off vs. dollar amount off
...
Also, in general what do you find works well when it comes to promotional emails that promote specific sales and special offers? Would love to get some feedback on your processes here. Thanks!

elements.text:

Also, in general what do you find works well when it comes to promotional emails that promote specific sales and special offers? Would love to get some feedback on your processes here. Thanks!
